body.p: To His Excellency B. Magoffin Gov. of Kentucky

Your petitioner Henry Hudson respectfully represents, that some few months ^since^ he became bound in a recognizance, as surety for one John H Miller, in the Jefferson Circuit Court, for the sum of Five Hundred dollars. Miller was indicted in said Court for stealing about fifteen dollars from Frederick Volk ins Volkins and Miller not appearing at the ^last^ November term of said Court, the recognizance was forfeited, and about ten days ago, Judgment was obtained against this petitioner and execution issued

Miller had been employed as a clerk in the store of this petitioner, about a year before the imputed offence, and had conducted himself honorably, and faithfully; and on that account and from sympathy, for him, this petitioner was induced to become bound for him in the recognizance.
Petitioner also believed that he was innocent of the charge.

Volkins ^Miller^ got into a frolic with the man who is said to have lost
the money. When asked for it Miller readily admitted he had it, and surrendered it. When Miller was bailed, he applied to this petitioner to permit him to go and seek work, none could be obtained by him in the City of Louisville. And this petitioner as , and Miller went into the Southern part of this state, and petitioner believes he would have returned, and stood his trial but he was unable to get to Louisville. Petitioner believes he will yet return, and stand his trial.

Your petitioner states that he has not received any remuneration, or indemnity, on account of his liability as Bail for Miller, and in these hard times of ^payment of^ the five Hundred dollars as exacted of petitioner it will be impossible to raise ^the^ money and petitioner will be either compelled to go to Prison, or have his property (which is but little) entirely sacrificed. In this view of the matter your petitioner respectfully asks that you will respite the execution a reasonable time
in order that he may produce Miller; and if that cannot be done to raise the Money and pay off the execution. for the five Hundred dollars. The execution is now in the hands of the Sheriff

Your petitioner earnestly hopes that time will be allowed him. If it should be refused, the loss to him, will be most oppressive. Your petitioner has long been a resident of Louisville, and he trusts and believes that no one would be willing to impute to it the commission of any wrong
subscribed & sworn to by Henry Hudson this 25th day of Jany 1862
Geo. W. Johnston. J. C. C. L.
We the undersigned are well acquainted with Henry Hudson and we unite in his petition for a respite of the execution.

Geo. W. Johnston.
Wm F Barret
If the Governor has any power to respite the execution I hope he will exercise it in behalf of the petitioner
Respite granted for six months. 16 Jany 1863

J F Robinson
Jefferson Cir. Ct
Issd Jany 16 1863
H. Hudson

Jefferson Cir. Ct
Respited for 12 months
Jany 27th 1862
$500. } Recog
Henry Hudson
